conclusion: To find the magnitude of the external force F applied to slider B, we need to analyze the forces acting on both sliders A and B.
Two sliders A and B are placed on an inclined plane with an angle θ = 37°.
A constant horizontal force F is applied to slider B to the right.
The coefficient of kinetic friction between the sliders and the inclined plane is μ = 0.5, and the maximum static friction is equal to the kinetic friction.
It is known that sin 37° = 0.6, and the gravitational acceleration is g.
Slider A has gravitational force mg acting vertically downward.
Slider A has normal force NA perpendicular to the inclined plane.
Slider A has frictional force fA acting down the incline.
Slider A has tension in the rope T acting up the incline.
Slider B has gravitational force mg acting vertically downward.
Slider B has normal force NB perpendicular to the inclined plane.
Slider B has frictional force fB acting down the incline.
Slider B has tension in the rope T acting down the incline.
Slider B has external force F acting horizontally to the right.
For Slider A, parallel to the incline: T - mg sin θ - fA = 0
For Slider A, perpendicular to the incline: NA - mg cos θ = 0

premise: fA = μ NA = μ mg cos θ
conclusion: For Slider A, frictional force: fA = μ NA = μ mg cos θ

premise: F cos θ - T - mg sin θ - fB = 0
conclusion: For Slider B, parallel to the incline: F cos θ - T - mg sin θ - fB = 0

premise: NB - F sin θ - mg cos θ = 0
conclusion: For Slider B, perpendicular to the incline: NB - F sin θ - mg cos θ = 0
